name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

key_work.title: Technicolor
key_work.brief_description: The first star of a Technicolor feature film was Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932.

constellations_primary.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

start.title: Technicolor
start.brief_description: The first star of a Technicolor feature film was Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932.

constellations_primary.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

end.title: Becky Sharp
end.brief_description: Adapted from a play that drew inspiration from William Makepeace Thackeray’s novel “Vanity Fair”, the film explores the English class system during the era of the Napoleonic Wars, but more importantly, is the first feature to use three-strip Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: The first live-action feature to be filmed in Technicolor was Becky Sharp, an adaptation of William Thackery’s acclaimed novel Vanity Fair.

start.title: Becky Sharp
start.brief_description: Adapted from a play that drew inspiration from William Makepeace Thackeray’s novel “Vanity Fair”, the film explores the English class system during the era of the Napoleonic Wars, but more importantly, is the first feature to use three-strip Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: The Wizard of Oz
end.creator_credit: Adrian, Arthur Freed, Mervyn LeRoy, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Malcolm Brown
end.brief_description: When a tornado rips through Kansas, Dorothy (Judy Garland) and her dog, Toto, are whisked away in their house to the magical land of Oz. They follow the Yellow Brick Road toward the Emerald City to meet the Wizard, and encounter a Scarecrow, a Tin Man and a Cowardly Lion.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Communicating colour
constellations_other.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

constellations_other.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_other.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

constellations_other.name: Dragon's Lair
constellations_other.description: A look at pop-cultural interconnections that spawn from the lair of Don Bluth's arcade classic.

links.description: When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz. As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, sheâ€™s enveloped in glorious Technicolor.

start.title: The Wizard of Oz
start.creator_credit: Adrian, Arthur Freed, Mervyn LeRoy, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Malcolm Brown
start.brief_description: When a tornado rips through Kansas, Dorothy (Judy Garland) and her dog, Toto, are whisked away in their house to the magical land of Oz. They follow the Yellow Brick Road toward the Emerald City to meet the Wizard, and encounter a Scarecrow, a Tin Man and a Cowardly Lion.

end.title: Flowers and Trees
end.brief_description: Flowers and Trees is a 1932 Silly Symphonies cartoon produced by Walt Disney, directed by Burt Gillett, and released on July 30, 1932. It was the first commercially released film to be produced in the full-color three-strip Technicolor process.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

links.description: One of the first and most iconic films released in Technicolor was The Wizard of Oz, though the three-strip Technicolor process was first used by Disney for their animated short film Flowers and Trees.

end.title: Suspiria
end.brief_description: From the moment she arrives in Germany to attend the prestigious Tanz Academy, American ballet-dancer Suzy Bannion (Jessica Harper) senses that something horribly evil lurks within the walls of the age-old institution.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: The Suspense Constellation
constellations_other.description: An exploration of music in suspense works.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards todayâ€™s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: The Wizard of Oz embraced the effect of Technicolor to portray a dream-like fantasy world. Suspiria went a different way, using Technicolor to create a heavily saturated, nightmarish atmosphere.

start.title: Suspiria
start.brief_description: From the moment she arrives in Germany to attend the prestigious Tanz Academy, American ballet-dancer Suzy Bannion (Jessica Harper) senses that something horribly evil lurks within the walls of the age-old institution.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary

Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

end.title: The Aviator
end.creator_credit: Charles Evans Jr., Graham King, Matthias Deyle, Michael Mann and Sandy Climan
end.headline_credit: Germany and United States of America, 2004

video_links.name: The Aviator | Official Trailer (HD) - Leonardo DiCaprio, Kate Beckinsale, Cate Blanchett | MIRAMAX

end.brief_description: A biopic charting the life of filmmaker and aviation magnate Howard Hughes between 1927 and 47, when his meteoric rise was impacted by his severe obsessive-compulsive disorder. Directed by Scorsese, digitally emulated the look of Technicolor to reflect the film’s era.

constellations_other.name: Communicating colour
constellations_other.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

constellations_other.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_other.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Some like it hot
constellations_other.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

links.description: While Suspiria was one of the last films to be made before the Technicolor process was phased out, The Aviator digitally emulated the look of Technicolor films between 1927 and 1947, which is the period the film is set.

start.title: Flowers and Trees
start.brief_description: Flowers and Trees is a 1932 Silly Symphonies cartoon produced by Walt Disney, directed by Burt Gillett, and released on July 30, 1932. It was the first commercially released film to be produced in the full-color three-strip Technicolor process.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

end.title: Cuphead
end.brief_description: Cuphead is a classic run and gun action game inspired by cartoons of the 1930s, with the visuals and audio painstakingly created with the same techniques of the era like traditional cel animation, watercolor backgrounds, and original jazz recordings.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_other.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

constellations_other.name: Timeless early animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

links.description: Flowers and Trees helped define the visual style of early animation. Videogame Cuphead uses an animation style that pays homage to this Technicolor era, even using many of the animation techniques that appeared in Flowers and Trees.

end.title: The Cuphead Show!
end.brief_description: Follow the misadventures of the impulsive Cuphead and his cautious but persuadable brother Mugman in this animated series based on the hit video game.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Timeless early animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

links.description: Cuphead‘s charming, 1930s style animation has proved so popular that the game was adapted into an animated series.
